title: Xianya Fu
text:
This project is about a ‘pqnumber’ Calculator.
To simulate how the computer handle the computation with large floating point numbers we define pqnumber objects to keep large numbers. This object should have four integer components. The first one is either +1 or −1. It gives the sign of the number. The second and third are p and q. And the fourth component is an integer vector of p + q + 1 integers between zero and nine. For example, we can use the following object x to keep the number 87654.321.
x <- structure(list(sign = 1, p = 3, q = 4, nums = 1:8), class = “pqnumber”)
p = 3 and q = 4 with nums = 1:8 has the decimal value: 0.001 + 0.02 + 0.3 + 4 + 50 + 600 + 7000 + 80000 = 87654.321

a <- pqnumber(1,3,4,1:8)
b <- pqnumber(1,6,0,c(3,9,5,1,4,1,3))
c <- pqnumber(-1,5,1,c(2,8,2,8,1,7,2))
is_pqnumber(a)

[1] TRUE

is_pqnumber(b)

[1] TRUE

is_pqnumber(c)

[1] TRUE

print(a,DEC = TRUE)

[1] 87654.321

print(b,DEC = TRUE)

[1] 3.141593

print(c,DEC = TRUE)

[1] -27.18282

print(c,DEC = FALSE)

sign = -1 
p = 5 
q = 1 
nums = 2 8 2 8 1 7 2 



#as_pqnumber(87654.321,3,3)

as_pqnumber(3.14159265358,11,0)

sign = 1 
p = 11 
q = 0 
nums = 8 5 3 5 6 2 9 5 1 4 1 3 

as_pqnumber(-27.18282,5,1)

sign = -1 
p = 5 
q = 1 
nums = 2 8 2 8 1 7 2 

as_pqnumber(0.1234,4,2)

sign = 1 
p = 4 
q = 2 
nums = 4 3 2 1 0 0 0 

as_pqnumber(1000,2,3)

sign = 1 
p = 2 
q = 3 
nums = 0 0 0 0 0 1 

as_pqnumber(1000,0,3)

sign = 1 
p = 0 
q = 3 
nums = 0 0 0 1 

as_pqnumber(3.145,2,0)

sign = 1 
p = 2 
q = 0 
nums = 4 1 3 

as_pqnumber(12345,0,4)

sign = 1 
p = 0 
q = 4 
nums = 5 4 3 2 1 

as_pqnumber(123.001,4,4)

sign = 1 
p = 4 
q = 4 
nums = 0 1 0 0 3 2 1 0 0 

as_pqnumber(123.001,2,4)

sign = 1 
p = 2 
q = 4 
nums = 0 0 3 2 1 0 0 



m <- pqnumber(-1,1,0,c(3,4))
n <- pqnumber(1,0,1,c(6,9))
l <- pqnumber(-1,0,1,c(6,9))
o <- pqnumber(1,1,0,c(3,4))
add(n,m)

sign = 1 
p = 1 
q = 1 
nums = 7 1 9 

add(n,o)

sign = 1 
p = 1 
q = 2 
nums = 3 0 0 1 

add(pqnumber(1,0,0,0),m) # 0 - 4.3

sign = -1 
p = 1 
q = 0 
nums = 3 4 

add(pqnumber(1,1,0,c(1,0)),pqnumber(1,1,0,c(1,0))) # 0.1 + 0.1

sign = 1 
p = 1 
q = 0 
nums = 2 0 

subtract(m,l)

sign = 1 
p = 1 
q = 1 
nums = 7 1 9 

subtract(l,m)

sign = -1 
p = 1 
q = 1 
nums = 7 1 9 

subtract(m,n)

sign = -1 
p = 1 
q = 2 
nums = 3 0 0 1 

subtract(pqnumber(1,0,0,2),pqnumber(1,0,0,2)) # 2 - 2

sign = 1 
p = 0 
q = 0 
nums = 0 



x <- pqnumber(1,1,1,c(5,4,1)) # 14.5
y <- pqnumber(1,1,3,c(3,6,1,1,1)) # 1116.3
as_numeric(multiply(x,y)) # 14.5 * 1116.3

[1] 16186.35

as_numeric(multiply(pqnumber(1,0,3,c(0,0,0,1)),m)) # 1000 * -4.3

[1] -4300

multiply(pqnumber(1,2,0,c(1,0,0)),m) # 0.01 * -4.3

sign = -1 
p = 3 
q = 0 
nums = 3 4 0 0 

multiply(m,pqnumber(1,1,0,c(1,0))) # -4.3 * 0.1

sign = -1 
p = 2 
q = 0 
nums = 3 4 0 

as_numeric(multiply(pqnumber(1,1,0,c(1,0)),pqnumber(1,2,0,c(1,0,0))))

[1] 0.001

multiply(pqnumber(1,0,2,c(0,0,2)),pqnumber(1,0,2,c(0,0,3)))

sign = 1 
p = 0 
q = 4 
nums = 0 0 0 0 6

title: Xianya Fu
text:
I’m Xianya Fu, a senior student currently studying at UCLA. My major is statistics and data science, and mainly focusing on the research and application of statistics and computer science related fields. I will graduate in June 2025 and continue my graduate studies in Data science.
